Literature Review: Lipids play pivotal roles in cellular functions, including membrane formation, energy storage, and signaling. The complexity of lipid metabolism and its implications in diseases such as cancer and autoimmunity have underscored the importance of understanding lipid dynamics at the single-cell level. This literature review explores the advancements in analytical techniques for single-cell biochemical assays of lipids, focusing on mass spectrometry, Raman imaging, and fluorescence-based assays including microscopy and microseparations. The heterogeneity in cell behavior and lipid signaling necessitates precise and sensitive methods to quantify lipids within individual cells, a challenge compounded by the small cell volume and the vast diversity of lipid species. Mass spectrometry (MS) has emerged as a powerful tool for single-cell lipidomics, offering high sensitivity and the ability to identify and quantify a wide range of lipid species. Recent developments in MS techniques, such as matrix-assisted laser desorption/ionization (MALDI) and electrospray ionization (ESI), have significantly improved the spatial resolution and sensitivity of lipid detection in single cells. Raman imaging, another non-invasive technique, provides detailed chemical information based on the vibrational modes of molecules, enabling the spatial mapping of lipids within cells without the need for labeling. This method has been particularly useful in studying lipid distribution and metabolism in live cells. Fluorescence-based assays, including microscopy and microseparations, offer high specificity and sensitivity for lipid detection. Techniques such as fluorescence resonance energy transfer (FRET) and fluorescence lifetime imaging microscopy (FLIM) have been employed to study lipid-protein interactions and lipid dynamics in single cells. Microseparations, including capillary electrophoresis (CE) and thin-layer chromatography (TLC), have been adapted for single-cell analysis, allowing for the separation and quantification of lipid species with high resolution. These advancements in analytical techniques have significantly enhanced our understanding of lipid biology at the single-cell level, providing insights into the roles of lipids in health and disease. However, challenges remain in terms of sensitivity, throughput, and the integration of these techniques for comprehensive single-cell lipidomics. Future directions may include the development of multimodal approaches that combine the strengths of different techniques to achieve a more holistic understanding of lipid metabolism and signaling in single cells.
